item.description:
A Monopoly variant based in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area of Minnesota. Comes with a 1-page sheet that gives a short history of the Twin Cities.

From the instructions: "Entrepreneurs acquire Business Licenses, develop Offices, and purchase various goods and services (thereby stimulating the local economy)... Accumulate the portfolio of business holdings with the greatest net worth."

About NationalOpoly Sales Corporation: "Headquartered in San Diego, California, has produced city games in Chicago, Detroit, Honolulu, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Sacramento, and San Diego. Nationalopoly has made a commitment to aiding community organizations in each of these cities. As a result, NationalOpoly will contribute a minimum of $.50 of every Minneapolis-St. Paul game sold to the Boys & Girls Club of Minneapolis."

Splash Mountain Sorry! is one of the tin boxed Disney Theme Park Editions. They are only sold at Disney resorts and theme parks. The playing pieces represent the log boats that guests ride through the attraction on.

The game Sorry! The Disney Edition a normally boxed version sold in regular stores, with themed “teams” of characters from multiple Disney films.

Players roll a die & move around a circular board filling opponent's (and their own!) teacups full of sugar cubes, spoons & squirts of water from a centrally located teapot. Players are eliminated from the game when their cups overflow.

Quaint late '60s offering from Ideal. Plastic shelters are assembled on the roll-out plastic gameboard before players spin & move. In addition to regulation numerals on the spinner, there are 'umbrella' and 'rain' areas. Players spinning the umbrella get to slot the small plastic umbrella provided with the game in the allocated position in their mover's hand where it remains until the umbrella is spun by an opponent. If 'rain' is spun, all players without the umbrella must return to the closest previous shelter passed on the road.

The first player to reach the finish space is the winner and gets to squirt the losers with the hose (optional house rule).

The Hippo's are bathing. They like their privacy, and surround themselves with rocks and plants. They don't like crocodiles!

In this simple but fun kid's game, players draw and place cards around each other's Hippos. Plants score positive points, crocs negative.

The animals are going out and must get dressed. Players are shown an animal's outfit and try to find the necessary clothes. The Hippopotumus' stripey bra? The Elephant's top hat? You can't let the animals go out naked!
Another quick word game, this has the trick that the letters can be read any which way up. That h could be a y, that Z is an N. Players scramble to get the best words from the cards on the table.

Nurkanvaltaajat is a Finnish economy game where you're supposed to gather a certain amount of property as soon as possible by buying and selling shares of companies. An unlucky situation can lead a player to bankruptcy and out of the game.

Prices of the shares vary randomly according to share price cards and a player can sometimes be offered with cheap shares. Players use pencil and paper to stay on track with their stock portfolios because the amount of shares isn't limited.

The goal of the game is decided by the players so its playing time may vary a lot.

Both players have to reach other side of board (enemy's island) and have to choose the way to reach it faster than opposite player.
During the journey the ships can try to sink enemy’s ship shooting them.

Players have to make a pool of cards copying exactly the pool locked in twisting plastic structure.
The fastest one gain victory point and the twisting were replaced by other cards.

name.value: The Hottest Race in the World

item.description:
This six player game is an upgraded version of Formula 1 Fever, which allows gamers to experience the thrills of F1 racing in the comfort of their own home. Gamers have the choice of competing in a single race or the entire F1 championships playing on the different race tracks similar to the actual F1 Championship.

Each player (driver) has an identical deck of movement cards, which also represents their fuel, so if at any time during the game they run out of cards, they are out of the game!

Before the race, players are given 12 construction points to customize their cars according to how they think it will race best on the track selected (the basic game comes with 2 tracks - Malaysia & Japan). Players can choose from better:
- Acceleration (1 point).
- Braking (1 point).
- Cornering (2 points).
- Special features (3 points).

The race is over 3 laps, and players begin with 5 cards from their deck, and 3 "Event" cards (which introduce elements such as rain, safety car, etc).

Each round, players starting with the race leader:
1) Decide if he/she wishes to play an "Event" card. The effects take place immediately.
2) Must play 1 "Movement" card and MAY play 1 other card (Acceleration, Braking, Cornering or Special).
3) Players then move their cars according to the modified score of their cards.

As in real life, players have to really plan how to negotiate the corners, where penalty points in the form of tire wear is imposed if players pass the corners. Essentially, players who land on the corners receive no penalty.

Players also have to plan tactically when to make their pit stops, and whether they take a short one (just top up petrol), or a longer one (where they also change tires).

In the end, players who manage their resources well, take risks at the right time and plan their pit stops well will emerge the winner!

Hudson River Sloops simulates trade along the Hudson River during the early 1800's. The river cargo was transported by the sloops navigating the tricky winds and waters of the Hudson. Cargo was shipped between New York and Albany. There are 10 river ports and 8 commodities. Commodities vary in worth its source distance from Manhattan and market condition.

"The Optical Illusion Game
The only game played backwards!"

A series of 10 'projects' or challenges that are timed. The fastest wins. All projects involve a blind and a mirror, so that the players must accomplish the feats by looking at the reflection.

The object of the game is to be the player whose dragon collects the most magical ring using the tail-pulling mechanism.

Once you begin, you and your friend(s) race to hook rings on to your dragon's tongue, pull its tail so that its neck bends back and drops the ring into the ring container and repeat. You can also use your dragon to try and knock rings off the tongues of opponent dragons. Once all the rings are gone, count them up. Whoever has the most wins.

Because there are three different colors of rings you can easily institute variants where certain color rings are worth more than others.

Z CARDZ are special pre-punched cards that can be assembled into 3-D models.

Z CARDZ the Game allows you and an opponent to build an army of these Z CARDZ. Through the use of special formation cards, you try to be the first one to KO all of your opponents Z CARDZ.

Booster packs contain 5 models and a matching playing card for each model. Pack contents consist of 3 normal models and 2 "special" models, colored in either metallic silver (rare) or metallic gold (ultra-rare). 60 different models are available in booster packs, each having a normal, rare, and ultra-rare version, resulting in a set size of 180 models.

item.description: This version of Monopoly is themed after the Disney/Pixar films: Toy Story (1 & 2), A Bug's Life, Monster's Inc., Finding Nemo, and The Incredibles. Special collectible tokens include: Woody, Nemo, Buzz Lightyear, Sulley, Mr.Incredible, and Flick.

item.description:
This version of Monopoly is one of the tin boxed Disney Theme Park Editions. They are only sold at Disney resorts and theme parks. The famous rides and attractions are bought, sold, and traded by the players. Main Street USA buildings act as houses while Disney castles sub for hotels. Eight collectible player tokens modeled after various ride modes of transportation are also included.

The game Monopoly: the Disney Edition (2001) a normally boxed version sold in regular stores with properties based on Disney films.

item.description:
Two players face off with their deck of Marvel Superheroes. For every battle, you compare the power numbers on their respective Hero cards with the highest number winning. Other cards, such as Power cards and Teamwork cards, can be used to bump up the power total or bring other Hero cards into play respectively.

Counters are used to bet on the outcome of a turn, with the first player to 30 points worth of counters being the winner.

item.description:
Transportation Tricks is a trick taking card game wherein the suits and values are separated into two different decks. Players bid to set the value of tricks in the various suits, and then play out the hand as in any typical trick taking game.

Transportation Tricks has been self published (at prototype quality) in an edition of 13 copies. All information on the status of the print run (including information on acquiring copies for however so long they remain available) will solely be available in the Announcements forum for the game here on BGG.

Atlantic City Jackpot was published as a marketing tie-in with the Resorts International Atlantic City Casino and Hotel. Players take the role of gamblers spending a week in Atlantic City, high rolling their way to a fat life of riches and glamour. Each turn around the board constitutes one day of play time, during which the active player may gamble on craps, blackjack, the slots, and other games of chance. At any point the non-moving players may place side bets in favor of the moving player or the house.

This card game is intended for 2 to 4 children ages 3 to 9. The game can be played three different ways.

1. PIGGY BANK: The entire deck is dealt to all players. Each turn a player turns over one card from his or her dealt pile. A card showing a nickel or five pennies is "banked". Other cards are placed in the center of the table in the "till". When a player draws a card that will match a card in the "till" to make five cents, those two cards are "banked". Cards can only be "banked" in two (or one) card combinations. The Silver Pig card is worth 10 cents -- two tricks. The player with the most money wins the game and becomes the next dealer.

2. DIME BANK: Plays like "Piggy Bank" except that players "bank" 10 cents instead of 5 cents, and the Silver Pig is worth 20 cents. (It is unclear how to avoid the two-card limit in this version.)

3. CONCENTRATION: This version is similar to the game card game Memory. It is for any number of players. Players "bank" pairs to add up to either 10 cents or 5 cents. A player's turn ends upon turning up the Silver Pig card. The game ends when there are two cards left, and a player uncovers a five-cent card and then the Silver Pig; this combination is worth two tricks.

The 1964 version has two different games.

The Disney character cards are numbered 1 to 10 with four cards of each suit. However, the suits are red hearts, yellow sunbursts, blue five-pointed stars, and white daisy flowers. There are also four Donald Duck cards of a "wild" shamrock suit. The #1 cards are Mickey Mouse, the #2 cards are Minnie Mouse, the #3 cards are Pluto, the #4 cards are Thumper, the #5 cards are Goofy, the #6 cards are Dumbo, the #7 cards are Clarabelle, the #8 cards are Flower, the #9 cards are Daisy Duck, and the #10 cards are Chip 'n' Dale. The last card is an instruction card.

Game 1: The four #1 cards are placed face-up on the table. The remaining cards are shuffled and dealt to each player. The player to the left of the dealer begins by playing a #2 card on a #1 card of the same color; this player can discard a second card by playing a #3 card of the same suit or any other #2 card. A player can only discard up to two cards per turn. A Donald Duck card is to be played as an #11 card to complete a pile. The first player to discard all his or her cards gains 10 points. A player must gain 50 points to win the game.

Game 2: The second game is similar to a version of Crazy Eights or Uno. Each player is dealt five cards. The remaining cards are placed in a face down stack with one card turn upright. Players discard cards by matching either the suit or number or by playing a wild Donald Duck card. When a wild Donald Duck card is discarded, it is played sideways so that the next player will have to match the card underneath by suit or number or with another wild Donald Duck card. The winner is the first player to discard all of his cards.

The 1965 version has three scenarios. The deck consists of 36 cards. The first card displays an advertisement for this product, the next two cards show a list of instructions, and the other 33 cards are divided equally between circus character pictures of heads, bodies, and legs.

Game #1: This version is essentially the only game. It is for 3 or 4 players. The head cards are divided equally among the players. The rest of the cards are mixed up and spread face down on the table. Player take turns revealing cards in a memory game type fashion. A player with a "head" card must uncover a "body" card while a player with "head" and "body" cards must uncover a "legs" card, otherwise the turn passes to the next player. The first player to complete all of his funny characters wins the game.

Game #2: A player can divide the three types of cards into three piles for a solitaire version players where the sole player reveals a "head" card followed by a "body" card followed by a "legs" card, creating various funny-looking circus figures.

Game #3: A player can place the cards in numerical order to create a "flip-movie" by riffling the top of the deck with his or her thumb. (It might be noted that these different numbers and pictures on the backs of the cards could be used essentially as "marked cards" for the 3 to 4 player game.)

One of the only two tactical wargames produced by the New Deal company. Italian language.

The Battle of Hastings is one of the few truly decisive battles in history. On a single day Duke William of Normandy conquered a kingdom that had resisted Viking invasions for years on end, ending a line of Anglo-Saxon kings that claim decent from Alfred the Great. This conquest altered the whole outlook of England, taking a nation that had looked towards Scandinavia, especially under three Danish kings, and locking her into a partnership and a struggle with France that was to last for centuries.

item.description:
One hundred and seventy-five years into the future - Humanity has managed to survive despite itself, but for how much longer?

Infinity is a game with 28mm high metal miniatures that simulates combat and special operations in a science fiction environment with Manga aesthetics.

The Great Powers in conflict are: PanOceania, the Superpower: Leadership & Technology. Yu Jing, the Asian Power: Modernity & Tradition. Haqqislam, the New Islam: Wisdom & Bravery. Ariadna, the Lost Colony: Resistance & Tenacity. Nomads, the Nonconformists: Rebellion & Resourcefulness. The Combined Army, the Alien Threat: Power from Deep Space. Mercenaries, the Profession of War.

The Infinity game system is fast, spectacularly realistic and offers enormous tactical flexibility.

INFINITY uses a new and dynamic system that allows both players to be active during each turn.

Choose your army, select the best men and women to form your elite combat group, the mission vital, the hour has come!

item.description: Swinging Marbles has players trying to getting small marbles from one cup to another. The cups are on lengths of wire, 80cm lengths! Plug the wires into the base board and try to swing the marbles from one cup to another. It does what it says on the tin!

An offshoot of the original Coopetition game, the On the Go! edition has players competing and cooperating in the categories Act, Talk, and Draw. The game consists of dice, game cards, and a 30 second sand timer. Players role dice to determine what word and category will be in play and with whom they will be cooperating or competing. Designed to be played in teams of two or more. The game box is small enough to fit in a pocket or purse and is meant to be taken with to family gatherings or parties.

From the designer's website:

'About 10 years ago I wanted to design a game that suited my own needs. I played many wargames and although some were close to what my vision is of a perfect game there was always something to bother about.

'I played many many wargames, and many of them disappointing me. In my opinion a game should have a fine mix of these elements:

* fast pacing, simple and only relevant statics
 * depth, a good mix of planning, bluffing, fast thinking and random elements
 * flexible, can you implement scenarios, new elements, characters and objects?
 * rich, a fantasy world provides a rich world, there are almost no limits
 * epic, can you remember the games you played a year ago?
 * cheap, well you can actually download Warbands for free from this site. In return I ask you to enter the forums and join the discussions.

'These key-elements I kept in mind developing Warbands, I show no hesitation using elements from existing games to develop Warbands. Its really fun, fast-paced and has a lot of tactical depth.'

In the game Warbands you are represented by a hero-mage figure controlling a party of a few or maybe a dozen characters on a battlefield. This complete party is called a warband. Each character in the wardband has an unique name. With you controlling this warband you can play the provided scenarios or the ones you created yourself but the game is also designed to battle versus an enemy warband. In an arena or in the open, battle it out till the enemy character is destroyed.

http://www.warbands.info/

"It's something to talk about"
 All you have to do is get the "guesser"to SPEAK one simple word. Sounds easy doesn't it? In getting the "guesser" to SPEAK the word, you or your team can say just about anything, as long as it is in the form of a sentence and does not contain the "mystery word." Still sounds EASY doesn't it?
 The rules are straight-forward. You're in a team of three or more players. Pick a team mate to be the "guesser." You and the remaining team mates are given a mystery word. It is your job to create a sentence together, using one word at a time - one player at a time, with the goal of leading your "guesser" to guess the mystery word.
 For instance, if the mystery word is "ESCALATOR", one team mate might say "THIS"... The second team mate might go on to say "MOVES"... Then, from player to player, they continue the sentence ie. "YOU" "UP" "AND" "DOWN" "LIKE" "STAIRS" until your "guesser" says the word - ESCALATOR.

(text from the bottom of box)

The thrilling strategy game of high class, high risk, and high drama. Capture the most points in Diamonds, Gold, Jewels, and Money... .while avoiding being handcuffed.

Ages 8 and up and for 2 - 4 Players.

The object of the game is to be the "Swiper" who swipes the most cards and scores 1000 points first. Points are scored by swiping up combinations of cards through builds.

Richard Dengel's DTP upgrade of the Rebel Yell system.

Components:

Standard sized map
around 200 counters 
60 page rulebook (although it is one column, 12 point font) - maybe 24-30 page rulebook if professionally formatted.

This game consists of a deck of 36 square cards representing star systems and constellations. It is not only a game, but it may constitute an help for the realization of theatrical or narrative structures.

The players take three cards each an try to form a particular configuration before the other players. When such a configuration is done, the player says "TRIS" and puts the cards in his score stack. Another hand is dealt and so on, until the cards are over.

The scoring differs in the three version of the game (Base, Medium and Difficult). In the base games it is simply the number of cards captured, while in the other versions also the numbers on the cards are taken into account.

Game is a very simple grand strategic simulation of the war between Nazi Germany and the USSR from 1941 to 1945. It was designed for use in the "War studies" course run by the designer at King's College , London.

Game consists of;

 11 page rulebook including examples and historical commentary. Sections covered are;
 Map, Units, Sequence of play, Movement, Combat, Combat resolution, Advance after combat, Production, Victory and Initial set-up.
 
 40 counters.
 Hex grid map (7 hexes x 5 hexes) from Berlin to the Caucasus.




Each combat unit represents roughly 300,000 German/Axis troops, or a Soviet ‘front’ with half a million or more soldiers.

Turns are 3 months, starting with summer 1941.

Sequence of play


 Axis movement phase
 two friendly combat units may be moved;
 
 Axis combat phase
 fresh friendly combat units may attack as desired;
 
 Axis production phase
 spent units may be reinforced.
 



 Soviet movement phase
 two friendly combat units may be moved;
 
 Soviet combat phase
 fresh friendly combat units may attack as desired;
 
 Soviet production phase
 spent units may be reinforced / units created.

item.description:
Careful is a dexterity game similar to Villa Paletti and Jenga. In the set-up, players build a bell tower five levels high using the plastic colored support posts and floors provided, as dictated by the color dots on the floor levels. Supports are not placed on the top floor; a heavy plastic-enclosed bell structure is placed in the centre of this level, which sounds when the tower becomes unstable. Then comes the deconstruction.

A turn consists of spinning the spinner and removing a pillar of the color spun from any floor of the tower. The floor levels have channels cut in them that makes the movement and removal of the support posts a challenge. Players may manipulate the tower as necessary to remove the pillar, but all pillars removed on a turn that are not the spun color must be replaced before removing the objective support post. Play continues until the tower falls; the player causing this to occur receives no points for the round whilst all other players receive points based on the color and number of supports taken on their turns.

Players play a number of rounds equal to the number of players playing. The player who accumulates the most points is the winner.

item.description:
Or: "Hexagames - Sonderanfertigung für die 1. Spielertage, Essen 1983 - Das Rasante Kunstflugspiel - Mit do-it-yourself Spielregeln" (*) to give it it's full title.

This must be the most unremarkable game to have ever been presented on any of the Essen game fairs if it wasn't for a very small detail: it was the first promotional give-away game on the Essen fair ever. Maybe I'm selling it short. It was possibly also an entry in a whole new genre: make-it-up-yourself-gaming.

Jürgen Hagedorn from Hexagames was simply handing out 20x35cm sheet of paper, with a hand-drawn game board on it. Stuck to a corner was a small bag with 4 wooden cylinders and a dice. The drawing was very suggestive, but had no rules. Brilliant!

Whilst freebies continued to be used by various companies in an effort to get noticed, they often took the shape of fashionable and pointless pins that people could stick on their clothes, or, after a more inspired moment by Jumbo, were god's gift to gamers on Essen: jumbo-sized carrier bags - with appropriate logo off course.

For all the concentrated creative energy on show, it's amazing that it didn't seem to dawn on anyone what the potential of promo-games were when it came to getting people to your stand. It took until 1995 before the next noteworthy Essen promo-expansion appeared: Goldsieber's 13th constellation for "Sternenhimmel" (although this was not free). Kosmos followed in 1998 with a "robber-gang-figure" for "Die Siedler von Catan", probably embarrassed by the success of the game and in a genuine effort to thank the fans. But it wasn't until Hans im Glück released a player's expansion for its "El Grande" that the promo floodgates truly opened. Hans im Glück is possibly still the worst offender with an endless flood of yearly "Carcassonne" add-ons. But where Hans led, many followed, and any visitor to the Essen Fair these days will find roaming bands of keen players trying to snaffle up all the special Essen promos on offer. It is rumored that not all of these end up on eBay. I won't join the debate weather this is racketeering or entrepreneurial. I do however applaud the recent initiatives from certain game companies to claw some of those eBay profits back, by no longer offering these promos for free, but asking a small donation for charity instead. Everyone a winner.

The game itself, off course, hardly got noticed and was easily forgotten. What do you expect from a sheet with a large plane and a game-of-goose type track of fluffy clouds that have different shapes but lack any explanation?

Nevertheless, now the "Essen Freebie Game (Expansion)" has became a bit of an institution, it might be time to pay tribute to the very first one: Hexagames, we salute you with a BGG entry for what must have been a great laugh.

(*) If you are left wondering: "Hexagames - Specially made for the first Essen Game Fair 1983 - The Speedy Stunt Plane Game - With Do-it-Yourself Rules"

From Black Powder's Website:
The Species Conflict

The year is 2038.

Man has grasped deep into the ocean, the wild lands, and into the orbital space, colonizing and tearing resources for the peoples use in a darkening future.

The future at a glance seems hard, for the birth of Risen animal species to intelligence and form like the human kind. Species hatred flares as humans have employed these new lifeforms where humans deem fit. Life has been hard for the Hybrids and the Risen, often worked to their deaths in colonial construction.

As well, many humans are fearful that they may be placed the loser in species conflict. Older folk are afraid of the frog, rat, and feline folk that now live next door.

All the while the Corporate Lords take their due as new leaders of the 21st century.

Welcome to Pacifica, your role is as a thief and a soldier. Leaders of Buka Units such as yourself will do battle, live as a rogue, and all the while laugh at those who do not know honor and freedom. Southeast off the shore of Japan, is where you are needed as the the 1,000,000 souls of the Pacifica Ocean Settlements are at odds with seeming rebels. These insurgents may be backed by powerful forces, so beware.

Pacifica makes its pay from oil drilling, tourism, research programs, and especially, the Titan Naga Platform that taps and collects geothermal energy from the earths core.

Of course, the internet now exists as both the wire of mother earth, and as playground. Webcrawlers with HUD net access fly as Deva across the shadowy illusion that is the Cybernet. Pays to keep a few of those people around.

Some, like yourself, will make their pay by covert operations. Welcome Buka rogue,

Enjoy your stay.

The game is a build-it-yourself PDF download. It includes a modular board, units (infantry, vehicles, and weapons) a rulebook, and 44 cards used to represent background "cyber-combat," or the opponents' wrestling for control of the computer system of the building they are in. Physical combat is decided by a more conventional roll-to-hit system. Rules are included to simulate combat in flooded and fully submerged locations.

This game is out of print.

name.value: Sailor Moon: Web of the Negaverse

item.description:
From Box:

"Queen Beryl, and her wicked minions have banded together, casting a Negaverse power into our universe. They've managed to capture Sailor Moon. You, with the other Sailor Scouts must join together to rescue her...and save our universe."

Roll-a-Role is a game in which the participants become actors presenting three minute dramas focused on particular situations. And they're not only actors, they provide their own script and direction.

All that's required is a free-spirited and imaginative group of players - Roll-a-Role provides the rest!

Based upon the mid-1970's U.S. television show S.W.A.T. (Special Weapons And Tactics). Players compete to have their SWAT teams (each player controls two) be the first to capture the fleeing culprit. Players load their teams into a truck and race to the various hideouts where the culprit lurks. The teams disembark and attempt to get to the space occupied by the culprit by exact count.

An action packed family boardgame, fast playing with lots of give and take. The secret plans keep moving and players must remember what parts are in the vault!

Each player is a spy attempting to steal the blueprints for a SECRET WEAPON from the inventors laboratory. The first agent to decode the blueprints on the decoder card is the winner.

(from MMP website:)

The war in China-India-Burma theatre is always looked at as through a veil; perceived as a backwater front of the far larger conflict that was World War Two. Nevertheless, this war was vital to the final Allied victory in the Pacific, and even more so to the impact this war would have on the post-war world. Many “what-ifs” could have dramatically changed the world. What if China had surrendered in 1937 and over a million Japanese soldiers would be free to overrun India. There would be no Flying Tigers or Doolittle's Raid, or even Pearl Harbor. If Japan could have mobilized Chinese manpower, the world as we know it might not exist.

War of the Suns (WotS) was first designed by Leonard To, a Hong Kong native, more than 20 years ago. It won the championship of the First Wargame Design Competition in Hong Kong in 1984. The game has since been updated in the early 90's, and extensively again during the last 3 years. Offering exclusive research based on recently opened Chinese archives, as well as many Japanese and English sources, has made War of the Suns one of the most painstakingly researched and accurate games of its type ever made.

The title of the — "War of the Suns", refers to the flags of Kuomintang China and Imperial Japan. The game itself covers the period from July 1937 to August 1945. The roughly 1:3,000,000 map covers most of China proper, Burma, Assam area of India, and parts of Thailand and Indochina.

There is a campaign game as well as 5 separate scenarios, and the game can be played as a 1-4 players' game-with players taking the roles of Japanese, KMT, CCP, and British Commonwealth. In the game, politics will play as vital a role in how the game progresses as the units presented on the map.

Other key game concepts include: 

 The HQ activation system - Players move units under the activated HQ. The number of activated HQs is affected by command points, the quality of HQ selected, and whether China is cut off from foreign routes. Randomness and quality of the HQ affects who moves what first.
 The KMT replacement system - KMT units are divided into 3 levels: The elite units with imported weapons; the standard units equipped with what Chinese herself produced; and the local units which simply bought whatever they could find locally.
 The Political Affiliation system - Each warlord and minor country has its own home territory. They may be affiliated with different players at different levels under different conditions. Friend may become foe with a random or historical triggering event.
 The Guerilla System - From the setting up of guerrilla bases to a unique combat system, Guerrilla actions from CCP, KMT, and even British player can be as active as the front line.
 Optional Rules - The game does not shy away from controversial subjects such as wartime atrocity, opium production, and Japanese collaborators. It also includes an "alternate history" section that probes into many "what if?" situations, e.g. what if Stilwell has not been recalled, but instead was capable of commanding all the Chinese forces?




War of the Suns Scale:

 Game Turn: 3 months
 Counters: Army [marked as Corps on counters]/Division for the Chinese; Division/Brigade for the Japanese and British [/Western Allies]




Game Details:

 Players: 1-4
 Scenarios: 5
 Complexity: Medium to Hard
 Playing Time: 5 to 34 hours




War of the Sun Components:

 3 22"x32" mapsheets
 1 8-1/2"x11" map overlay
 10 countersheets (176 counters on each countersheet)
 36 page rulebook
 56 page playbook
 8 player aid cards
 4 six-sided dice





International Game Series game from Multi-Man Publishing.

The war in China-India-Burma theatre is always looked at as through a veil; perceived as a backwater front of the far larger conflict that was World War Two. Nevertheless, this war was vital to the final Allied victory in the Pacific.

Scenarios:

 Mini scenarios:
 Fist of Fury - Shanghai area, 3 turns, 1937-38
 Retreat to Victory - Changsha area, 2 turns, 1941-42
 Double Gamble - Imphal (Burma) area, 2 turns, 1944
 Plan B - South China area, 2 turns, 1945-46 (hypothetical)
 
 Operational Scenarios:
 Space for Time - 2 maps (North & Central), 5 turns, 1937-38
 Battle for Changsha - 2 maps (North & Central), 13 turns, 1938-42
 Operation Ichi-Go - 3 maps, 6 turns, 1944-1945
 
 Campaigns:
 Campaign game without special turn 0 (same start as "Space for Time" scenario)
 Chinese Campaign (without Burma) - starts turn 0 or 1
 Burma Campaign (without China) - starts turn 19
 




Adam Starkweather provided development of the design, and Mark Mahaffey the map for the game. Counters are by Bruce Yearian.

item.description:
A game from Japan, it is a cross between a dexterity game and a wagering game.

Players are real estate barons investing in high rises. On a players turn, he rolls as many dice as there are floors in the building in which he is invested. These "floors" are composed of dice with 0-4 windows on them. As floors are stacked, they must ascend from 0 to 4, and then back around. After a player rolls, he determines how many floors he can and wants to build. If he builds at least 5 floors, he earns $10K. If he builds the tallest building (with a minimum of 15 stories) he gets $10K. If he knocks his building down, all of the investors in the building pay $20K.

Play for three rounds, and the player with the most cash wins.

item.description:
Three Australian environmental card games for the whole family. For ages 4 and up.

Play Go Anna! and enjoy classic games with an Australian twist.
Play Go Anna! and learn about Australia's unique wildlife.
Younger children develop skills in recognizing colors, words and Australian animals. They develop skills in counting and memory.
For older children there are challenge levels to develop creativity and lateral thinking skills.
Go Anna! features beautiful, whimsical illustrations by Caitlin McDougall, talented actor and artist. Games design by Kribo and Yodit Ackerman.

The three games in the set are:

Go Anna!: Collect sets of possums, wrens or other animals in this fun four-of-a kind game.

Cinnamon's Surprise: Cinnamon the superb blue wren will help you win all the cards in this fast paced game.

Ella & Louis' Wonderful Connections: Match up one Tawny Frogmouth card with another, or birds with birds, mammals with mammals and so on, in this great matching game.
In sound effects you are trying to be the first team to correctly guess as many oral sound effects as possible and advance clockwise around the game board from start to finish.

The side of the card packet displays the name as the "Mickey Mouse Card Game" while the front cover displays the name as the "Mickey Mouse: Educational Card Game" and inside card instruction displays the name as the "Mickey Mouse Number Game".

Most of the cards have either green circles that represent Mickey Mouse, red circles that represent Donald Duck, blue circles that represent Pluto, or yellow circles that represent Goofy.

The game can be played with two to four players. The four-player game can be played with a set of two partners. The game begins with each player being dealt 4 cards. Three cards are placed face up in the middle of a table, although the 3-player game requires five cards to be placed face up in the middle of the table instead of three.

Players can claim cards in three ways.

1. By matching: A player can claim a card that matches on in his or her hand.
2. By combining: If there is a Mickey Mouse "Lucky One" on the table, a player can form a +1 addition equation to place this card on another card already on the table and pick it up with a next highest number card in the player's hand.
3. By building: A player can attempt to form an addition equation to pick up a set of cards. For example: If there is a "3" on the table, a player can place a "4" on a "3" to build a "7". If player can use a "7" card next round to pick up the "4" and "3". However, this player could lose this "4 + 3" in two ways. Another player could take this "4 + 3" before next turn by playing a "7", or another player could attempt to build a higher number equation by placing another card on the "4 + 3" stack. However, a player cannot build unless he or she has a card to pick up the stack.

A player that cannot match, combine, or build must place one card on the table. The player making the last play takes any cards left on the table. A player gets 3 points for having the most cards, 2 points for a Lucky 2, 2 points for a Lucky 10, and 1 point for a Lucky 1. The player or team that is the first to get 25 points wins the game.

name.value: Man at War: The Game of Crisis and Conflict

item.description:
Man at War is a trivia game where players (or teams) move their pieces through 5 layers of the Pentagon.

Each trivia card has 5 categories of questions:

1. Commanders
2. Troops, Units and Installations
3. Battles and Campaigns
4. Traditions, Uniforms, Decorations and Insignia
5. Weapons Systems

On the outer layer of the Pentagon, players are required to answer 1 question to continue their turn. Each layer that players move towards the center of the Pentagon requires the players to answer an additional question to continue play, until the center of the Pentagon is reached where players are required to answer all 5 questions on a trivia card. If all 5 questions are answered correctly, the player received the rank of General of the Army. If any question is incorrectly answered the player must return to the start of the game and begin again or "gracefully resign" out of the game.

This game is similar but different from "Fouray" or "4 Player Chess". The biggest difference might be that traditonal "4 Player Chess" has 96 open spaces in the initial setup while Forchess only has 4 open spaces.

There are two version to this game.

1. Standard Forchess has fixed alliances
2. Cutthroat Forchess focuses on fluid alliances

In this game, four traditional chess sets are placed on the smaller and traditional 8 by 8 board with one pawn removed from each player's side, meaning that conflict occurs quickly due to a lack of available space. In this version, the pawns move forward diagonally and capture forward vertically and forward horizontally, but they can never move more than one square at a time and thus there is no "en passant" capture technique in this game. Castling does not exist in Forchess. It is suggested that kings should be captured like other pieces, although opponents should still say "check" when putting a king in jeopardy. Furthermore, a player cannot place a teammate in check. If a player cannot move any of his pieces, he must remove one piece from the board per turn until he can move a piece. If a player captures a king, he may then use all of the removed player's pieces!

(From the back of the box)

Bible Rummy
Jumbo Card Game

Now families with young children can enjoy this popular game with a spiritual bonus.

 12 beautifully illustrated stories from the Bible
 Jumbo-size cards are easy for little hands to hold and organize
 No reading required
 Set contains




48 brightly colored story cards.
 1 instruction card with Bible story references
 1 Faith Parenting card

This game is best played in a largish area with the competitors sitting in a circle on the floor. A plastic basket containing a coiled 'snake' is placed in the center of the players. The 'snake' consists of a large, material-covered spring with a plastic head on one end. The basket has a number of holes, one of which will activate the latch on the basket and release the snake.

Players select a colored Swami & place it in position at the base of the basket closest to them. During the game, players are not permitted to move their hands away from their Swami unless it is their turn or their name is called during play.

Players start the game with 5 snake tokens each. A turn consists of paying a token into the 'snake pit', calling out an opponent's name and pressing a hole in the basket.

If nothing happens, the player can elect to continue their turn for as long as they want, rotating the basket, pressing successive holes & calling out an opponent's name each time, paying a snake token into the snake pit before each press. Whenever a player manages to get rid of all their snake tokens, they take a ruby from the 'treasure trove' and a fresh set of 5 snake tokens from the snake pit. A player may end their turn at any time without having released the snake.

If the snake is released, the relevant opponent must catch the snake or they are penalized - they must return one ruby to the treasure trove or take 5 snake tokens from the snake pit if they have no rubies.

If the snake is successfully caught, the caller must give the opponent one of their own rubies. If no ruby is owned, the opponent gives the caller all the snake tokens they currently hold and - since they now have no more snake tokens - they take a ruby from the 'treasure trove' and a fresh set of 5 snake tokens from the snake pit.

Any player who erroneously attempts to catch the snake or otherwise removes their hands from their Swami at an unauthorized time during play is penalized. They receive a snake token from each of their opponents.

The first player with 5 rubies is the winner.

(From the publisher's website - http://www.faithkids.com)

Family Choices Board Game - Proverbs Edition
"Applying the Biblical Wisdom of Solomon to Everyday Situations"
ISBN/SPCN: 9834503369 Item #: 101588
Size: 14 X 6.5 X 2"

Families! Play this game together and know where you are spiritually!

* Anne Marie has a great singing voice, but another girl got picked for a solo part at church. Anne Marie got angry and wanted to stop going to church. What would you say to her?
 * Dad says no tattoos, but how would he ever know unless Megan shows him? Shouldn't she be able to make her own decisions? It's her body, isn't it?
 * Mom found out her friend at work was going to be let go, but she told her boss she wouldn't tell. Should she keep her promise to her boss or should she be loyal to her friend and let her know?

Making the right choices in life can be tough. But with the help of Family Choices: Proverbs Edition, learning to make the best decisions becomes exciting entertainment!

Make Family Choices part of your Family Night fun, and get ready to come face-to-face with some of life's toughest real-life issues--issues we all face in today's world. Learn how real heroes of the faith, such as Solomon and his descendants, got wisdom for living by following God's laws. Now you can follow their example by talking about and learning eighteen Proverbs from the popular NIV translation of the Bible. Designed to be played by all the members of a family--from the youngest to the oldest--Family Choices: Proverbs Edition will become a favorite family activity. Included are a colorful game board, six player markers, 150 situation cards, 6 principle cards, and an instruction/reference booklet.

A card game based on the table snooker ball game. Each player starts with seven card(ball)s. The top cardball from the deck is turned over and becomes the 'option cardball'. A player then takes either the option cardball or the top card from the deck and then places a card on top of the option cardball. A player may then make a break. A minimum break consists of a white cardball, a red cardball and a colored card ball (following the rules of snooker). As the red cards are played they are placed in the pockets in the snookard box. Later the colored balls will also be played into these pockets. A player replenishes back to seven cards. A scoreboard is also provided. The winner of the frame is the player with the highest number of points when the final black is potted. There are also special cards: miscue, snooker, foul, safety shot and free ball.
Magnificent Czech game about two armies . Each army wants to destroy the others' castle.

item.description:
This is a gambling game developed and produced by Rick R. Windedahl. He states in the acknowledgment that he developed the game in 1977 for personal home play and that after 5 years of private play he was urged to get a copyright and publish the game.

The object it to become a Billionaire. Each player starts with 300 million dollars and the game continues until only one player is left with money or one player accumulates 1 billion dollars in assets.

The game comes with 300 chips, 16 casino tiles, 6 tokens, 5 dice, 4 betting strips, a gameboard, a slots deck, a regular deck a spinner and the rule book.

Players roll either 1 or 2 dice (their choice) and then move around the board and either play the gambling game of the casino that they land on for small profits against the bank or buy the casino (casinos are grouped, sort of like Monopoly squares, by the same color) and then own and become the bank for that particular casino making the payoffs for others who gamble in that particular casino. The games of chance in the game are SLOTS, WHEEL, DICE, BLACKJACK, ACEY-DUCEY and various forms of POKER. (There is an explanation on how to play any of the games included in the rule book..

Acquiring a set of the same colored casinos allows one to get a bonus by selling them back to the bank for double the buying price.

Sometimes the wording of the rules shows perhaps a lack of proper English and so are not as clear as they could be.

A strategy game where one person takes the roll of the Cowboys (along with their cows) and the other takes the roll of the Rustlers (along with their horses).

The players take turns rolling the die and moving a piece, within the grid on the board, attempting to steal your opponents livestock or attempting to throw your opponents cowboys/rustlers in prison.

The first player to capture their opponents 11 cows/horses or 3 cowboys/rustlers wins.

Be the first player to complete a day trip to Whistler (in B.C. Canada).

-Drive the awesome route from Horseshoe Bay to Whistler Village

-Ski three challenging runs on the mountains

-Then return to Horseshoe Bay

Box Contains:
1 Gameboard
1 Die
6 Pawns
20 "miss turn" tokens
18 Ski run medals
11 Chance cards
11 Apres ski cards
6 First aid cards

All players start on the street. The youngest player spins first and moves his/her playing piece the number shown on the spinner. Play continues with the next player on the left.

Players can move from side to side along ledges, and they can move up using fire escape ladders, windows, or Batropes.

The first player to climb from the street to the top of the building and saves Robin wins.

name.value: Batman: The Chase Through Gotham City

item.description:
The eerie quietness of Gotham City has been shattered by the sound of the prison alarm. The Chase Through Gotham City has begun!

With the forces of good and evil racing to the hideout - who will win? Will one of the villains get to the hideout and go free or will one of the heroes get to the hideout first and block the entrance?

This game features glow in the dark game board, pieces, and spinner.

"Face-Off was designed to provide fine family entertainment for children and adults in conjunction with promoting their awareness of hockey. This game offers sociable, stimulating, exciting, competitive action." -From Instruction

Players roll the dice and move around the board attempting to land on the Goal spaces while trying to stay out of the Penalty Box.

The first player to score 5 goals is declared the winner.

item.description:
From Box:

"Kaleidomaze is a simple to play board game in a new dimension, which offers you the most unique experience of zigzagging through a maze - AN EVER CHANGING MAZE!

The object is to score from your opponents by taking over their BASEs and trapping their SUBJECT tokens in the maze with your STRESSOR peg. It sounds easy! But remember that your opponents are also trying their best to do the same - taking over your base and trapping you in the maze. Under these competitive conditions, the players manipulate the existing maze into a dynamic ever changing maze, that is KALEIDOMAZE.

As in life, very often you than CHANCEs (cards) for better or worse; and occasionally save one or two CREDITs (cards) to be used under certain adverse situations. Sometimes you may encounter such a dilemma of being trapped by your competitors; but fortunately many times you are able to develop intricate strategies and tactical moves to revert the embarrassment. Very often, your goal appears so close and yet it suddenly becomes so far. Many times, it appears so unlikely and yet it suddenly becomes so easy. This is KALEIDOMAZE.

You need strategy, judgment and luck to win the game. The rules are simple, and the skillfully designed gameboard and playing pieces allow you a wide choice of moves. This puzzling maze, being manipulated by you and your opponents, many times is very rewarding, but can also become a frustrating and aggravating challenge."

Each player starts the game with millions of "Empire Mania" dollars; and then proceeds to collect assets by purchasing teams and free agents, collecting bonuses, winning points for the League Standings, and staying clear of the Penalty Box Squares. As well, you can trade Teams and Free Agents - a strategy that can make you a bundle, or cost you a fortune.

Imagine the thrill of buying your favorite teams of the NHL, combined with the excitement of developing your own strategies to win the game. The player who has the greatest financial empire at the end of the game wins!

(This game was an Official Licensed Product of the NHL)

Opponents roll balls down one of two tracks on the plastic gameboard, depending on whether they are the 'offense' or 'defense' for that particular play. One track is straight; the other meanders in progressively diminishing arcs. There are catching depressions where the tracks intersect, each worth a different score if the meandering balls are knocked off the track by the defense. Two balls are launched down the meandering track; the defender is allotted four balls to prevent these from reaching their intended destination.

A default 15 points are awarded to the offense for each ball that successfully reaches the end of the meandering track. Points are scored by the defending player for each ball of the offense that FAILS to reach the end of its path, according to the amount on the depression that the ball rests in.

After each play opponents swap roles.

The first player to accumulate 300 points is the winner.

name.value: Nickelodeon Clarissa Explains It All Game

item.description:
Based on the quirky Nickelodeon situation comedy Clarissa Explains it all, this game captures much of the angst and annoyances of the lead character Clarissa.
Players answer questions picking from five predetermined answers and creating one of their own. Each of the predetermined answers garners a certain amount of spaces to be moved based on the answers popularity in a "survey of Clarissa's friends." If any players match their made-up answers each player collects one of twelve keys in six colors from the center or another player. Moving takes place simultaneously with each player preforming the action on the space they land on.
Certain spaces lead to Crisis cards, which can be countered with collected Rescue cards. Others allow players to attempt to win a Driver's License by picking three numbers and attempting to roll one of them on a die. Still other spaces just allow you to "hang out" or go get a snack.
If a player makes it around the whole board with at least one key and a Driver's License they choose one of six Car Cards and try to match the color of one of their keys. First player to match a car and a key wins.

item.description: "Company, play the principles" is a board game issued by Siemens probably to educate their personnel about corporate values. Players have to move through the 5 values (People, Innovation, Value, Responsibility, Customers) to reach the goal. In each player's turn the movement is driven by dice for the player and a whirling arrow for all the players together.

"Take your Time" is a game issued by CGIL (one of the Italian Union of Workers). Players plan their 24 hours day with activities hour by hour (sleep, work, shopping, stadium, dancing and many others) and go around the city to complete their plan. Players can help each other to have a better life.

There is unrest on the farm! Fridolin Fox is on the prowl. All animals run and hide in the bushes. Save the animals by bringing them into the safety of the stable. Who will save the most animals before the fox finds them?

There are 7 tiles with bushes placed on the table. Upon these bushes there are placed six sound devices. So one bush isn't occupied. When a player pushes on the devices it makes the sound of an animal. (dog, cat, duck, frog, rooster, pig). Then the 30 cards are shuffled and placed, face down, around the bushes.

In a players turn, the player turns around a card and must find the correct animal sound. When the player has turned on a device, the device is moved to the empty bush. If the sound and the card are matching, the player keeps the card and plays again.
If Fridolin Fox is the turn end. The player places the fox on the foxholes. The game ends when all six the foxes are found.

The player with the most cards wins the game.

From manufacturer's website:
With Numaro, the answer to every question is an amazing numerical fact, which allows every player to guess on each question. The player with the guess closest to the actual answer wins the round. For example, how many episodes of the TV show, The Cosby Show, was produced? (Answer: 204) .

1850 is set in the Midwestern United States to the west of Chicago. It is another in the series of 18xx games originated by Francis Tresham, and is most closely related to 1870: Railroading across the Trans Mississippi from 1870, also by the same author.

Companies involved in the game include CB&Q, CMStP&P, CRI&P, GN, MKT ("Katy"), MP, NP, Soo Line, and UP.

The Bratz Babyz have left their stuff all over town. The players travel around the board gathering their baby's items. The first player to collect and deliver seven of their nine items is the winner. Management of action cards (each allows the baby to move in some fashion and then to take an action on the board) makes this game far more interesting than most aimed at the same target audience.

name.value: Freddy Vs Jason Killer Trivia Game
Friday the 13th & A Nightmare on Elm Street Killer Trivia Game

item.description:
The bloodbath continues, but now it’s your turn to slay. Jason Voorhees and Freddy Krueger, the most iconic cinematic serial killers of our time, have nothing on you. Recount your knowledge of all ten "Friday the 13th" films, seven "A Nightmare on Elm Street" films, and the only "Freddy vs. Jason" film in an effort to collect corpses and accumulate enough bodies to win.

Choose to play a “Friday the 13th” trivia game with 500 questions, testing your brainpower on 2 decades of atrocious homicides. Or play an “A Nightmare on Elm Street” trivia game with 500 questions to keep you wide-awake through Freddy’s dreamy killing spree. And if you have enough time for a double homicide, play a combo game for twice the scare.

With over 1,000 questions, a custom die, and coroner’s reports that challenge you to recount the gruesome ways that Freddy and Jason slaughtered their victims, this trivia game is sure to provide frightening fun for all horror film fans.

Ages 17 and up 2+ players

Sword & Spear - Individual Man-to-Man Combat in Ancient and Medieval Times

"Sword & Spear is a set of wargame rules for small skirmishes in the millennium before effective gunpowder weapons. Each player commands a small detachment (two to ten figures) in a battle of close-range missile and hand-to-hand combat. Although most attractive when played with metal or plastic painted figures mounted on stands, various substitutes or just the stands can be used instead." Includes section for "mythological gaming."

24-page rulebook, including tables, for miniatures game.

This game is based on the Bratz DVD movie. Players portray the Bratz trying to save their magazine by traveling around the world (I.e. the game board) and performing rock concerts. The first player to collect 10k in cash is the winner.

Liar!, challenges players to determine the identity of a card placed face down in the middle of the table. They take turns asking each other questions; the twist is that each player can lie once during the game.

Liar! was a finalist in the 2005 About.com Deduction Game Design Competition.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: In a similar game to his Barbarossa, this Klaus Teuber game has players molding clay with the attempt to make figures that are just hard enough not to guess immediately, but not so hard as not to be guessed.

This is a promotional game made by Nordic chocolate company Cloetta. Board setup reminds you slightly of Talisman as players wander around outer regions collecting stuff before entering the middle area of the game. No fighting though.

Theme is to gather en expedition and then enter the jungle and transport cocoa to the harbor. A simple roll and move game, collect items (guide, provisions, tent, weapons, guide and pack horse), get trade goods (cocoa) and then get money for it. First player to a certain amount wins.

From the box :

The "7 fighting kingdoms" is a strategy and diplomacy game, taking place in the antique China.
Each player is leading a kingdom; his aim : Unify China, and by all means, war or negotiation, money or betrayal, because in order to be the China master, you must be a great general as well as a fine politician.

Including :
800 counters
1 color map
7 game charts
1 rules booklet
Rules for 2 to 7 players
Complexity : 7/10

Synopsis:

Ten activity games that can be played inside or outside the house. Truly a party in a box. Find the red triangle, then the blue party hat, then the square birthday cake. The last one there will be too late. This is your invitation to FUN, FUN, FUN.

The game pieces are incredibly durable and the pictures are cute! If you are familiar with the storybook character, Corduroy, than you know the cute bear sketch that I am referencing. In addition to the bears, there are party hats, cakes and presents. The floor tiles assist toward shape and color recognition. I enjoy observing which/how many children count the candles on the cake(s) (there are five). And because there is a connection, via the character, to books... it is my belief that this game inspires reading...this set is best suited, for day care, preschool or kindergarten aged children. It would be great in the classroom; especially with the storybook, as a compliment.

Out of the 10 activity games 3 are non-competitive while the other 7 are competitive in which case the winner receives prize tokens.

LOOPING is a simple card game with the theme of aerobatics. Each card represents the side view of an aircraft completing a maneuver - climbing, diving, looping or some other similar action.

The start card shows an aircraft taking off and to this players add further cards in a sequence with the smoke trails on the cards indicating where two cards can be connected together. The card also indicates the difficulty of the stunt - and the points gained if the maneuver is successfully completed.

Then idea of the game is to attempt to add cards allowing the aircraft to gain and lose altitude undertaking a variety of tricks on the way. Whether the trick is achieved or not is determined by a die roll (throwing higher than a given number shown on some of the cards). Points are earned for a successfully completed maneuver. If you fail any part of the sequence then you score nothing.

The game ends when the aircraft is brought in to land, through the laying of the appropriate card, at a level at the same altitude from which it took off. The winner is the player who scored the most points during the flight.

The game has three variants OVER THE CLOUDS (3-5 players) DARE-DEVILS (2-4 players) and SKY-RIDER (3-6 players)which, though broadly similar, do make the game suitable for differing numbers of players.

Features two game boards! Start out on Skull Island and try to be the first player to find King Kong. Then take a ship to New York City and get past the military planes to the skyscraper. Save Kong and win! Features 3-D game board and parts. For 2 to 4 players.

A simple wargame on the battle of Arsouf (1191) between Richard the Lionheart and Saladin. This game is quite similar to Bouvines 1214 of the same publisher. It includes some nice chrome such as the Naffatums. The game materials are entirely in French.

Lako's School Days Game is an education board game for children ages 4 and up. During game play, players draw cards with pictures such as red pizza, blue mittens or yellow giraffes and then attempt to classify the pictures into color, number and object categories. In a turn, a player may count grapes or socks, match blues or reds, and group donuts with food or squirrels with animals. Success moves Lako along the game board’s sidewalk path and the winner is the first to get Lako to the red schoolhouse.

Along the way, children land on Lako spaces which award school activity cards such as Lako doing homework at his desk, or Lako showing his name tag in show & tell. These cards educate kids about school activities and create a positive attitude toward them by rewarding children with advances on the board.

From the publisher's website:
Submission was developed for the true wrestling fan, by true wrestling fans. Whether you watch wrestling on television, or attend local wrestling events, this game will test your wrestling knowledge to the fullest in a fun and creative way. With 7 intense modes of gameplay, over 100 unique categories, the INSANITY of the Tap Out Deck, and Mini-Games that really mix things up, you and your friends can battle it out for hours, until one person is crowned the Submission Champion!

This is the Cayman Island themed version of Monopoly. Community Chest has been renamed to Pirate's Chest and many properties have been renamed based on sponsors. A 2005 revamp was released to raise money for the Cayman Islands' Junior Achievement program.

link.value: Junior Achievement Company of Defiance, Ohio

item.description: This was an official NFL release. It is not related (directly) to Trivial Pursuit. Players answer trivia questions about the NFL. Of course, records post-1992 will not be here, so don't answer "Barry Sanders" or "Emmitt Smith."

A children's game where you spin a dial to collect wages or other life experiences. Players try to move from the lower class to the middle class to the upper class. Winner is the first to reach a million dollars.

From the publisher's website:
Calculink is an adventurous math game that enhances your mental arithmetic as you link numbers to reach certain totals. Points are scored on each play and extra for bravery, while strategy is used to avoid traps and to block your opponents. You learn to master several math skills through the popular Calcutest cards, which offer fun-filled exercises on a range of school-based topics. And if you are a lucky, you just might pull the right Cue Card to give you that edge on your opponents.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Trivia game about wines. Choose to play as an amateur, professional or connoisseur. Roll the dice, move your cork and attempt to answer from 900 questions in six categories, Grapes, Region, Estate/Producer, Spirits, Fortified Wines and Vocabulary.

Monopoly Desi is the Indianised version of regular Monopoly. Players get to travel from Broadway in Southall, to the city’s Nehru Centre, stopping en route at Kiribati - all places associated with the Asian community in the UK.

Cutting a wider migratory map, the other important halts in the game’s four main travel squares include several Indian destinations such as New Delhi Station, Shivaji Chattrapati Station in Mumbai, Chennai’s Central Station and the Howrah station in Kolkata. Some of these zones even carry adverts on the expatriate tribe, Pataks curry pastes, Asian NGOs and, even one for an Indian cable TV.

ISONZO is a division level strategic game of the Bainsizza Italian offensive and the Caporetto counteroffensive on the Italian front in the 1917.
The game has 1 map, 332 counters, tables and rules

Tumbling Down is an abstract-strategy game played on a checker board with 58 pieces in two colors.

Gameplay involves moving stacks of pieces by tumbling them in one direction. Tumbled stacks leave one piece of the stack on top of anything on a square for each square it travels in that direction. The object is to capture your opponent's largest stack.

Online Play

 boardspace.net realtime against live opponents or robots
 Richard's Play-By-eMail Server (PBEM)

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Two games of love, intimacy and adventure. This game provides any couple from 18 on up, married, dating or living together, an atmosphere of fun while experiencing a romantic, intimate, pleasurable time together. Romantic Rendezvous extends the relationship’s foundation so a couple can grow closer, laugh and delve into the joys and delights of being together.

The board game offers over 120 different activities that are detailed on a beautifully designed board. During the game, you and your partner will have the opportunity to experience intimate sharing; romantic, loving, and playful activities; meaningful and informative communication; wishing, hugging, kissing and touching. The board game also provides bonuses and interesting twists that can add plenty of excitement!

The card game is a game of self-expression and communication, giving and receiving and will add some spice to your love life. The game consists of 54 Romance Cards that contain fun, playfully adventurous and intimate activities for you and your partner.

Playing the two games together adds an exciting dimension and creates the Romantic Rendezvous Experience. However, neither game is dependent on the other.

Playing is easy and both players WIN at every turn!

The first time you see Icehouse Pieces, you want to build something with them. This quick party game pits your balancing skills against that of others, allowing you to build piles up from three base pieces, but not allowing any easy stacking. The last pile standing wins.

Zagami is a game of Martian microbial life for four players. It requires a standard chessboard and a set of Icehouse Pieces.

Each player controls a single-colored colony of microbes, which moves and expands across the small meteorite in search of food. Multicolored stacks begin to form - microbes eating microbes eating microbes. As the game progresses, each colony evolves "enzymes" which allow it to metabolize other microbes into energy to be used for growing, sporing, attacking, and escaping. Only one colony will survive the long journey from Mars to Earth. Will it be yours?

item.description: Balancing Act Challenge is based on the Canadian government's Canada's Food Guide To Healthy Eating, which organizes nutritional needs into four food groups: grain products, milk products, vegetables & fruit, and meat & meat alternatives. The object of the game is to be the first player to collect the required number of each food group's Serving Cards. There are challenge squares that would allow players to challenge each other for food-serving cards. If a player lands on the Canadian flag, they may move anywhere on the board.

This is a game about 2 battles (Curtatone e Montanara and Goito) of the initial periods of the "Prima guerra d'Indipendenza" in the Italian Risorgimento.

Each battle has a map and a set of counters.
